items.title: What resources does Syrian President Assad still have to defend his rule? | DW News
items.author: DW News
items.content:
Islamist-led rebels in Syria captured the strategically crucial city of Hama on three sides, both the militants and the Syrian government said on Thursday.

"Over the past few hours, with the intensification of confrontations between our soldiers and terrorist groups... these groups were able to breach a number of axes in the city and entered it," the army said, adding that it had withdrawn from the city to prevent urban combat and the civilian death toll asssociated with it.

The UK-based Syrian Observatory for Human Rights said that the rebels were able to make significant advances in the last 24 hours, despite the government sending "large military convoys to Hama" and the surrounding area. They added that the Syrian army has been joined by Russian and Iranian officers, as both countries have been longtime allies of Syrian President Bashar al-Assad.

State news agency SANA confirmed that the government was waging "fierce battles" across Hama province, led by "joint Syrian-Russian warplanes."

German news agency DPA said that award-winning Syrian photographer Anas Alkharboutli was killed in one of the airstrikes on Hama.

#Syria #Assad #Hama
For more news go to: http://www.dw.com/en/

items.title: What could Germany's role in post-war Ukraine look like? | DW News
items.author: DW News
items.content:
A debate is brewing in Germany about what a peace settlement for Ukraine might look like — once the fighting stops. Foreign Minister Annalena Baerbock says Ukraine would need guarantees for its future security, and possibly NATO membership or an "international presence" to keep the peace. But what exactly could Germany contribute?

items.title: War and Peace: A Deal with Putin at the Expense of Ukraine? | To the Point
items.author: DW News
items.content:
What could the path to peace for Ukraine look like? The debate over possible scenarios for ending the war is intensifying every day, as President-elect Donald Trump prepares to take office in Washington. He has vowed to end the war quickly. Ukraine is under heavy pressure from intense waves of Russian attacks, despite promises of more weapons from Germany and the US. Trump's designated special envoy for Ukraine, General Keith Kellogg, has a plan to bring Ukraine and Russia to the negotiating table. 
But will Putin even consider it? President Zelenskyy may have to pay a high price for peace, especially if he wants to get the NATO protection he hopes for by temporarily giving up some territories…

On To the Point, we ask: War and Peace: A Deal with Putin at the Expense of Ukraine?

Our guests:
Rafael Loss, European Council on Foreign Relations, ECFR
Thomas Wiegold, Military Expert
Marina Miron, King’s College London

01:00 Introduction of guests
01:45 Current state of the war: Ukraine is short on troops
02:45 Russia faces high losses but can still absorb them 
03:20 Russia may deploy troops to Syria, weakening its position in the war against Ukraine
04:46 Both sides are suffering substantially
08:00 Freezing frontlines has not solved armed conflict in the past
10:20 Russia wouldn’t accept buffer zones between Russia and Ukraine
10:45 Ukraine doesn’t currently fulfill the criteria to join NATO
12:30 Germany doesn’t support NATO membership for a country at war
13:00 NATO is not prepared to deploy peacekeeping troops to the Russian border
14:30 If Europe doesn’t solve the problem, Russia may meddle in European affairs
15:20 The Ukrainian population is getting tired of the war, polls show
16:45 What happens if the war continues?
17:35 Elections in Germany might change the German stance
18:40 Europe has not boosted the military industry as required
19:15 France and Germany in crisis means trouble for Ukraine
21:10 The economy in Russia is deteriorating, risking the financing of the war
22:15 Europe can’t produce enough armaments for Ukraine
23:10 The sanctions against Russia don’t work; Russia is still selling oil
25:00 If the West hadn’t implemented sanctions, Russia would be even stronger today

#ukrainerussiawar #ukraine #diplomacy

items.title: How close are Islamist rebels to toppling Assad? | Ask DW
items.author: DW News
items.content:
Syrian rebel forces have taken control of the city of Hama, marking the latest advance in a week-long offensive against Syrian government forces. Hama is a strategically important city in the northwestern part of Syria, about 140 kilometers from the country's second-largest city Aleppo, which rebel forces took control of last week. The fall of Hama marks another setback for the Syrian regime of President Bashar al-Assad. What will the rebels' next move be? How long can Assad and his forces hold out? We take your questions, live in the studio.

items.title: After his government's collapse, can President Macron survive long enough to fix it? | DW News
items.author: DW News
items.content:
France's shortest-serving premier lost a vote of no-confidence in parliament yesterday - in a move supported by the left AND the far-right. It was the first time a French government had been voted down by parliament in more than 60 years. That ramps up the pressure on President Emmanuel Macron, who is struggling to pass much-needed reforms aimed at addressing mounting economic concerns. Meanwhile Macron has given a defiant television address,  saying he would appoint a new premier in the coming days - but he gave no hints as to who it might be. He blamed his opponents on the far right AND the far left for the defeat - accusing them of choosing disorder rather than working together to pass a budget. Macron also said he had no intention of leaving office before his term ends in 2027. 

With analysis from DW's Paris Correspondent Lisa Louis and Journalist Daniel Brown.

#macron #france #michelbarnier 

For more news go to: http://www.dw.com/en/

items.title: Live: Europe's ESA and India's ISRO launch Proba-3 mission to study Sun | DW News
items.author: DW News
items.content:
ESA’s eclipse-making precise formation-flying mission, Proba-3 is scheduled for launch on a PSLV-XL rocket from Satish Dhawan Space Centre in Sriharikota, India. The latest member of ESA’s family of in-orbit demonstration missions, Proba-3 is in fact two spacecraft being launched together. On Earth, total solar eclipses only occur every 18 months on average, and last just for a few minutes. Solar scientists have to travel all over the world to take advantage of them. Proba-3 will be able to create solar eclipses on demand, observing closer to the edge of the Sun than any previous Earth- or space-based instrument, down to just 1.1 solar radii.

Schedule:
10:38 GMT Liftoff
10:56 GMT Satellite separation

#Proba3 #ESA #ISRO

items.title: Can Delhi successfully combat vehicle polution? | DW News
items.author: DW News
items.content:
Delhi's air has become a health hazard. Toxic air blankets the city, with vehicles as one of the biggest culprits. Over 54,000 lives are lost annually, and millions suffer from respiratory diseases. But is change possible? With stricter car regulations, the rise of electric vehicles, and bold government action, hope is on the horizon.

items.title: Why this US tsunami warning was withdrawn, and why the long term threat remains | DW News
items.author: DW News
items.content:
Authorities in the US have withdrawn a tsunami warning after an earthquake struck off the Pacific coast.

The relatively shallow magnitude 7 quake struck about 70 kilometers off the coast of Northern California, in a sparsely populated area. Roads in the states of California and Oregon became clogged with traffic as people attempted to flee further inland. The National Weather Service initially issued a tsunami warning that covered almost 5 million people -- including the San Francisco area -- before announcing that the coast was clear.

Chapters:
0:00 The tsunami that never was
0:32 Matthew Cappucci, Meteorologist

items.title: Reports: Massive EU-Mercosur trade deal nearing finish line | DW News
items.author: DW News
items.content:
After years of negotiations, a massive trade agreement between the EU and the South American Mercosur bloc appears close to the finish line. EU commission president Ursula von der Leyen arrived in Uruguay this week for final talks. The deal would create a huge new trans-atlantic market, but there have been objections in the EU, especially from farmers.
